Casino Revenue Up 340% After Discovery That Pigeons Cannot Count

By Magistrate Sable Wingthorne • Investigative Correspondent

Municipal coffers have swelled to unprecedented levels following the Roost Casino's controversial decision to begin admitting pigeons to the low-stakes moss-covered blackjack tables last moon cycle.

"They keep hitting on 19," reported Pit Boss Edgar Taloncrest, who has overseen Table Moss Integrity since the casino's founding. "One of them split two kings. We didn't even know that was possible emotionally."

The Corvid Gaming Commission released figures showing the average pigeon visitor loses 47 seed-units per hour — roughly triple the rate of the typical crow patron, who at least has the dignity to lose slowly over an entire evening.

Chief Justice Cornelius Blackfeather III, who authorized the policy under Municipal Ordinance 8.3(c) ("Expansion of Revenue-Generating Activities to Non-Corvid Species, Excluding Seagulls"), called the results "a vindication of the court's progressive inter-species fiscal policy."

When asked if he felt any ethical concerns, the Chief Justice adjusted his moss-stained judicial collar and replied: "The moss doesn't judge. Neither do I. The cards judge."

"They keep hitting on 19. One of them split two kings. We didn't even know that was possible emotionally." — Pit Boss Edgar Taloncrest, Table 7

Moss Supply Chain Crisis Enters Third Moon; Court Surfaces Down to 40% Coverage

By Clerk Juniper Ashdown • Municipal Affairs

Section 4.7b of the Corvid Municipal Code mandates "full terrestrial coverage on all judicial and gambling surfaces" for hygiene, spiritual, and textural reasons. That statute is now, in the Chief Justice's words, "aspirational."

The crisis began when the court's primary moss supplier — a damp log behind the Shell station on Route 9 — was paved over for a Wendy's drive-through. Emergency procurement from the drainage ditch near Cedar Park has yielded only sphagnum moss, which the Gaming Commission classifies as "decorative, not regulatory."

"You cannot adjudicate a property dispute on sphagnum," said Chief Justice Blackfeather at Thursday's emergency session, his talons sinking into what he described as "inadequate moss." "It lacks the moral density."

The Roost Casino's roulette wheel is currently operating at 62% moss coverage, with the 00 pocket fully exposed. Patrons have been advised to avoid eye contact with the bare felt.

Editorial: The Bread Tax Was Just, and History Will Vindicate Me

Opinion by Chief Justice Cornelius Blackfeather III

I have been called many things. "Tyrant." "Bread hoarder." "That crow who keeps screaming outside the courthouse." All of these are accurate, and none of them diminish the soundness of my fiscal policy.

The bread tax — a modest 30% levy on all bread products found within the municipal perimeter — would have funded the casino expansion, resurfaced the perching rails, and finally settled the Long Dispute over the parking lot bread hierarchy.

Instead, the so-called "Breadless Coalition" — pigeons, mostly — filed suit, and this court, in a moment of weakness (I was molting), ruled the tax unconstitutional. My own court. Ruling against me. The audacity. The feathers.

The casino was the compromise. Remember that the next time you win 200 seeds at the moss-covered craps table. You're welcome.

Local Starling "Just Watching" at Roulette Table for 4 Hours

By Correspondent Ivy Quillson

A starling identified only as "Dave" has been standing motionless beside Roulette Table 3 since approximately 9:14 PM, placing no bets but maintaining what Pit Boss Taloncrest describes as "an upsetting level of eye contact."

"He's not breaking any rules," Taloncrest confirmed. "We checked. Twice. He's just... there. Watching the wheel. Sometimes he tilts his head."

Casino security attempted to offer Dave complimentary seeds, which he declined by not moving at all.

Corrections & Retractions

Correction: Last moon's edition stated that the roulette wheel is "rigged." We regret the error. The wheel is "calibrated for municipal revenue optimization." We apologize for any confusion.
Correction: The obituary for Gerald the Worm was premature. Gerald has been located. He is fine. He is in the moss near Table 4. Gerald, if you're reading this, you still owe the court 12 seed-units.
Retraction: We previously reported that pigeons "lack the cognitive architecture for strategic gambling." The Pigeon Anti-Defamation League has asked us to clarify that pigeons lack the cognitive architecture for all strategic thinking, not just gambling. We regret the incomplete characterization.
Correction: The horoscope section was not written by a licensed astrological corvid as previously claimed. It was written by the Chief Justice during what he describes as "a spiritual episode." Accuracy of predictions is unaffected.
